questions.text: All of the following are effective osmoles, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Certain solutes, particularly urea, do not contribute to water shifts across most membranes and are thus known as ineffective osmoles.

  • The solute or particle concentration of a fluid is known as its osmolality, expressed as milliosmoles per kilogram of water (mOsm/kg).
  • Water easily diffuses across most cell membranes to achieve osmotic equilibrium (ECF osmolality = ICF osmolality).
  • Notably, the extracellular and intracellular solute compositions differ considerably owing to the activity of various transporters, channels, and ATP-driven membrane pumps.
  • The major ECF particles are Na+ and its accompanying anions Cl- and HCO3 -, whereas K+ and organic phosphate esters (ATP, creatine phosphate, and phospholipids) are the predominant ICF osmoles.
  • Solutes that are restricted to the ECF or the ICF determine the 'tonicity' or effective osmolality of that compartment. (Other options ruled out)

questions.text: AVP secretion is stimulated as systemic osmolality increases above a threshold level of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

AVP(Arginine Vasopressin) secretion is stimulated as systemic osmolality increases above a threshold level of ~285 mOsm/kg, above which there is a linear relationship between osmolality and circulating AVP.

  • This is the primary stimulus for the secretion of the AVP.
  • Thirst and thus water ingestion are also activated at ~285mOsm/kg, beyond which there is an equivalent linear increase in the perceived intensity of thirst as a function of circulating osmolality.

Secondary stimulus:

  • Changes in blood volume and blood pressure are also direct stimuli for AVP release and thirst, albeit with a less sensitive response profile.
  • Of perhaps greater clinical relevance to the pathophysiology of water homeostasis, ECF volume strongly modulates the relationship between circulating osmolality and AVP release.
  • Such that hypovolemia reduces the osmotic threshold and increases the slope of the response curve to osmolality; hypervolemia has an opposite effect, increasing the osmotic threshold and reducing the slope of the response curve.

questions.text: The image below shows Vasopressin and the regulation of water permeability in the renal collecting duct. AT which receptor does vasopressin act?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vasopressin binds to the type 2 vasopressin receptor (V2R) on the basolateral membrane of principal cells, activates adenylyl cyclase (AC), increases intracellular cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), and stimulates protein kinase A (PKA) activity.

  • Cytoplasmic vesicles carrying aquaporin-2 (AQP) water channel proteins are inserted into the luminal membrane in response to vasopressin, thereby increasing the water permeability of this membrane.
  • When vasopressin stimulation ends, water channels are retrieved by an endocytic process, and water permeability returns to its low basal rate.
  • The AQP3 and AQP4 water channels are expressed on the basolateral membrane and complete the transcellular pathway for water reabsorption. pAQP2, phosphorylated aquaporin-2.

Explanation of other Options:

V1 Receptor (V1R)(Option A):

  • Location: Vascular smooth muscle, liver, platelets
  • Function: Causes vasoconstriction, increases blood pressure, promotes glycogenolysis and platelet aggregation

V3 Receptor (V3R / V1b)(Option C):

  • Location: Anterior pituitary
  • Function: Stimulates ACTH secretion; activates HPA axis

V4 Receptor(Option D):

  • Not a recognised vasopressin receptor in humans

questions.text: In which of the following situations urinary Na+ level more than 20 mM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non-renal causes of hypovolemic hyponatremia include GI loss (e.g., vomiting, diarrhoea, tube drainage) and insensible loss (sweating, burns) of Na+-Cl- and water, in the absence of adequate oral replacement; urine Na+ concentration is typically < 20.
  • In renal causes like Diuretic use, salt wasting syndromes and ketonuria, sodium is retained in the urine due to poor reabsorption and osmotic drag, hence UNais > 20

Causes of Natriuresis:

questions.text: All of the following are causes of salt-losing nephropathy, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thiazide diuretics cause hyponatremia via several mechanisms, including polydipsia and diuretic-induced volume depletion.
  • Notably, thiazides do not inhibit the renal concentrating mechanism, such that circulating AVP retains a full effect on renal water retention.
  • In contrast, loop diuretics, which are less frequently associated with hyponatremia, inhibit Na+-Cl- and K+ absorption by the TALH, blunting the countercurrentmechanism and reducing the ability to concentrate the urine.
  • Increased excretion of an osmotically active non-reabsorbable or poorly reabsorbable solute can also lead to volume depletion and hyponatremia; important causes include glycosuria, ketonuria (e.g., in starvation or diabetic or alcoholic ketoacidosis), and bicarbonaturia (e.g., in renal tubular acidosis or metabolic alkalosis, where the associated bicarbonaturia leads to loss of Na+).

Salt-losing nephropathies may lead to hyponatremia when sodium intake is reduced, due to impaired renal tubular function; typical causes include:

  • Reflux nephropathy(Option A)
  • Interstitial nephropathies(Option B)
  • Post-obstructive uropathy
  • Medullary cystic disease(Option C)
  • The recovery phase of acute tubular necrosis.

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.text: What is the common cause of SIADH?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Common causes of SIADH include pulmonary disease (e.g., pneumonia, tuberculosis, pleural effusion) and central nervous system (CNS) diseases (e.g., tumour, subarachnoid haemorrhage, meningitis). (Option A)
  • SIADH also occurs with malignancies, most commonly with small-cell lung carcinoma (75% of malignancy-associated SIAD); ~10% of patients with this tumour will have a plasma Na+ concentration of < 130 mM at presentation. (Option B)
  • SIADH is also a frequent complication of certain drugs, most commonly the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). Other drugs can potentiate the renal effect of AVP, without exerting direct effects on circulating AVP levels. (Option C)

choices.text: It occurs in alcoholics whose sole nutrient is beer
Typically, urine Na+ concentration is > 20 mM
AVP levels are expected to be suppressed in this condition
Resumption of a normal diet and/or saline hydration will correct the causative deficit

questions.text: All of the statements regarding 'beer potomania' are true, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hyponatremia can occasionally occur in patients with a very low intake of dietary solutes.
  • Patients with hyponatremia due to low solute intake typically present with a very low urine osmolality (< 100-200 mOsm/kg) with a urine Na+ concentration that is< 10-20 mM.
  • Classically, this occurs in alcoholics whose sole nutrient is beer, hence the diagnostic label of beer potomania. (Option A ruled out)
  • Beer is very low in protein and salt content, containing only 1-2 mM of Na+.
  • The syndrome has also been described in nonalcoholic patients with highly restricted solute intake due to nutrient-restricted diets, e.g., extreme vegetarian diets.
  • The fundamental abnormality is the inadequate dietary intake of solutes; the reduced urinary solute excretion limits water excretion such that hyponatremia ensues after relatively modest polydipsia.
  • AVP levels have not been reported in patients with beer potomania but are expected to be suppressed or rapidly suppressible with saline hydration; this fits with the overly rapid correction in plasma Na+ concentration that can be seen with saline hydration. (Option C ruled out)
  • Resumption of a normal diet and/or saline hydration will also correct the causative deficit in urinary solute excretion, such that patients with beer potomania typically correct their plasma Na+ concentration promptly after admission to the hospital. (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: Which part of the brain is most commonly involved due to rapid correction of sodium in extrapontine myelinolysis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8-10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) is also associated with a disruption in the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing the entry of immune mediators that may contribute to demyelination.

Central Pontine Myelolysis:

  • The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons, a neuroanatomic structure wherein the delay in the re-accumulation of osmotic osmolytes is particularly pronounced.
  • Clinically, patients with central pontine myelinolysis present one or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia with paraparesis or quadriparesis, dysphagia, dysarthria, diplopia, a 'locked-in syndrome,' and/or loss 301 of consciousness.

Extrapontine Myelinosis:

  • Extrapontine myelinolysis (EPM) is a form of osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS) that occurs outside the pons. It is often associated with the rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia.
  • Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in association with lesions of the pons but occasionally in isolation.
  • In order of frequency, the lesions of extrapontine myelinolysis can occur in the cerebellum, lateral geniculate body, thalamus, putamen, and cerebral cortex or subcortex. (Other options ruled out)
  • Clinical presentation of ODS can, therefore, vary as a function of the extent and localisation of extrapontine myelinolysis, with the reported development of ataxia, mutism, parkinsonism, dystonia, and catatonia.
  • Relowering of plasma Na+ concentration after overly rapid correction can prevent or attenuate ODS.

questions.text: Which ratio is the quick indicator of water deprivation as a treatment in Hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The urine-to-plasma electrolyte ratio (urinary [Na+] + [K+]/plasma [Na+]) can be exploited as a quick indicator of electrolyte-free water excretion.

  • Patients with a ratio of >1 should be more aggressively restricted (<500 mL/d), those with a ratio of ~1 should be restricted to 500-700 mL/d, and those with a ratio < 1 should be restricted to < 1 L/d.
  • In hypokalemic patients, potassium replacement will serve to increase plasma Na+ concentration, given that the plasma Na+ concentration is a function of both exchangeable Na+ and exchangeable K+ divided by total-body water.
  • A corollary is that aggressive repletion of K+ has the potential to overcorrect the plasma Na+ concentration even in the absence of hypertonic saline.
  • Plasma Na+ concentration will also tend to respond to an increase in dietary solute intake, which increases the ability to excrete free water; this can be accomplished with oral salt tablets and with newly available, palatable preparations of oral urea.

choices.text: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and measurement of ADH
Central diabetes insipidus and measurement of ADH
Lithium toxicity and measurement of serum lithium level
Increased solute load and measurement of electrolyte-free water clearance

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman sustained a stroke and is receiving enteral nutrition by nasoduodenal tube at a nursing home. She is transferred to the hospital with altered mental status. Nursing home staff reported that she had plentiful urine output 2 days before transfer. Laboratory data on hospital arrival reveal serum sodium of 165 mmol/l, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 60 mg/dl, and creatinine 1.6 mg/dl; all were normal 6 weeks earlier. Additional laboratory data include:
Serum osmolality of 341 mOsm/kg (NR: 275 to 295 mOsm/kg)
Urine osmolality 690 mOsm/kg (NR:500-850 mOsm/kg)
Urine sodium 7 mmol/l (NR:>20 mmol/L)
Urine potassium 32 mmol/l (NR: ~20 mEq/L)
The most likely explanation for this patient's polyuria and hypernatremia, and the most appropriate confirmatory test are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A calculation would reveal that this patient is excreting electrolyte-free water despite the urine osmolality being much greater than serum osmolality.

  • In such a patient setting, the failure to replace electrolyte-free water losses results in increased serum sodium concentration.
  • The hyperosmolality of the urine is primarily caused by the extremely high excretion of urea in this patient receiving high-protein enteral feedings.

Patients on enteral tube feeds, especially if protein-dense or urea-rich, can develop:

  • High osmotic load in the urine
  • Increased urinary solute excretion (Na+ + K+ + urea)
  • This leads to polyuria, free water loss, and hypernatremia.

Explanation of other options:

Nephrogenic DI(Option A): Urine should be dilute (low osmolality), but here it's concentrated.

Central DI: Same issue(Option B): Would cause dilute urine, but this patient has urine osmolality 690 mOsm/kg.

Lithium toxicity(Option C): No lithium history, and urine findings don't support nephrogenic DI.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man recently diagnosed with Small cell carcinoma presented to the Emergency department with a history of headache and confusion for one day. On examination, he was well; his BP was 140/70, other was unremarkable. Laboratory examination showed Serum Urea 8 mmoL/L, Serum creatinine 1 mg/dL, Serum Na 105 mmoL/L, Serum K 4.3 mmol/L. Due to his neurological finding, he was started on 3% normal saline on, 2nd day, his serum Na was 124 mmol/L, and he improved. The next day, he started to have slurred speech and exaggerated tendon reflexes while his serum Na was 130 mmol/L. T2-weighted MRI of the brain was done, showing hyperintense shadows in the brainstem area. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Diagnosis: Osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS), specifically central pontine myelinolysis (CPM).
  • Mechanism: Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia → osmotic injury to oligodendrocytes → demyelination, especially in the pons.
  • Typical risk factors:
    • Chronic hyponatremia (often from SIADH; here likely due to small cell carcinoma)
    • Correction rate > 8-10 mmol/L in 24 hours
  • Timeline here: Na+ corrected from 105 → 124 in 24 hrs (+19 mmol/L) - too rapid → high CPM risk.
  • MRI finding: T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in central pons without mass effect = classic for CPM.

Central Pontine Myelinolysis


Explanation of other options:

Ischemic stroke(Option A): Could present with slurred speech, but:

  • Not likely bilateral or brainstem-related
  • MRI would show focal restricted diffusion

Hemorrhagic stroke(Option B):

  • No mention of high BP, no signs of raised ICP
  • MRI would show blood signal (T1/T2 blooming)

Metastatic disease(Option D):

  • Small cell cancer can metastasise to the brain
  • But this presentation is too acute, and imaging would show mass effect, not a diffuse pontine signal

questions.text: All of the following are causes of NDI (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus), except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thiazides may reduce polyuria due to NDI, ostensibly by inducing hypovolemia and increasing proximal tubular water reabsorption. But it does not cause the Nephrogenic DI.

  • Hypercalcemia can also cause polyuria and NDI; calcium signals directly through the calcium-sensing receptor to downregulate Na+, K+, and Cl- transport by the TALH and water transport in principal cells, thus reducing renal concentrating ability in hypercalcemia. (Option A ruled out)
  • Another common acquired cause of NDI is hypokalemia, which inhibits the renal response to AVP and downregulates aquaporin-2 expression. (Option B ruled out)
  • Several drugs can cause acquired NDI, in particular lithium, Ifosfamide, and several antiviral agents. (Option C ruled out)
  • Lithium causes NDI by multiple mechanisms, including direct inhibition of renal glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK3), a kinase thought to be the pharmacologic target of lithium in bipolar disease; GSK3 is required for the response of principal cells to AV.P.
  • Occasionally, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have been used to treat polyuria associated with NDI, reducing the negative effect of intrarenal prostaglandins on urinary concentrating mechanisms; however, this assumes the risks of NSAID-associated gastric and/or renal toxicity.

Diagnosis of Nephrogenic DI:

  • In nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, the water deprivation test after an overnight fast shows the maximal osmolality of urine is abnormally l, ow < 750 mOsmol/ kg.
  • After administration of exogenous vasopressin (DDAVP), there is only a slight increase in urine osmolality.
  • In cranial diabetes insipidus, DDAVP produces a rise in urine osmolality of about 50%. In psychogenic polydipsia, a low initial plasma and urine osmolality.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of Hypokalemia, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trimethoprim does not cause Hypokalemia; in turn, it can cause hyperkalemia by decreasing the ability of kidney for the excretion of potassium.

  • Insulin,β2-adrenergic activity, thyroid hormone, and alkalosis promote Na+/K+-ATPase-mediated cellular uptake of K+, leading to hypokalemia.
  • Inhibition of the passive efflux of K+ can also cause hypokalemia, albeit rarely. This typically occurs in the setting of systemic inhibition of K+ channels by toxic barium ions.

Causes of Hypokalemia:

  • Exogenous insulin can cause iatrogenic hypokalemia, particularly during the management of K+-deficient states such as diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Alternatively, the stimulation of endogenous insulin can provoke hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and/or hypophosphatemia in malnourished patients given a carbohydrate load.
  • Alterations in the activity of the endogenous sympathetic nervous system can cause hypokalemia in several settings, including alcohol withdrawal, hyperthyroidism, acute myocardial infarction, and severe head injury.
  • β2 agonists, including both bronchodilators and tocolytics (ritodrine), are powerful activators of cellular K+ uptake. (Option A ruled out)
  • Hidden sympathomimetics, such as pseudoephedrine and ephedrine in cough syrup or dieting agents, may also cause unexpected hypokalemia. (Option B ruled out)
  • Finally, xanthine-dependent activation of cAMP-dependent signalling, downstream of the β2 receptor, can lead to hypokalemia, usually in the setting of overdose (theophylline) or marked over ingestion (dietary caffeine). (Option C ruled out)
  • Trimethoprim leads to hyperkalemia by inhibition of the ENaC epithelial sodium channel.

ECG Changes in Potassium Disturbances:

choices.text: It is caused by missense mutations of voltage sensor domains within the α1 subunit of L-type potassium channels
TPP develops more frequently in patients of Asian or Hispanic origin
TPP typically presents with weakness of the respiratory muscles with paralytic episodes that occur most frequently between 1 and 6 p.m
Hypokalemia is usually accompanied by hyperphosphatemia and hypermagnesemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements about TPP (thyrotoxic periodic paralysis) is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Redistributive hypokalemia can also occur in the setting of hyperthyroidism, with periodic attacks of hypokalemic paralysis (thyrotoxic periodic paralysis [TPP]).

  • Similar episodes of hypokalemic weakness in the absence of thyroid abnormalities occur in familial hypokalemic periodic paralysis, usually caused by missense mutations of voltage sensor domains within the α1 subunit of L-type calcium channels or the skeletal Na+ channel.
  • These mutations generate an abnormal gating pore current activated by hyperpolarisation.

Thyrotoxic Periodic Paralysis:

  • Develops more frequently in patients of Asian or Hispanic origin
  • TPP is associated with mutations affecting inward-rectifying potassium channels (e.g., Kir2.6, encoded by KCNJ18). (Option A ruled out)
  • Patients typically present with weakness of the extremities and limb girdles, with paralytic episodes that occur most frequently between 1 AM and 6 AM. (Option C ruled out).
  • Signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism are not invariably present.
  • Hypokalemia is usually profound and almost invariably accompanied by hypophosphatemia and hypomagnesemia. (Option D ruled out)
  • The hypokalemia in TPP is also attributed to both direct and indirect activation of the Na+/K+-ATPase, resulting in increased uptake of K+ by muscle and other tissues.
  • Increases in β-adrenergic activity play an important role in that high-dose propranolol (3 mg/kg) rapidly reverses the associated hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and paralysis.

questions.text: Metabolic profile of liquorice root ingestion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Liquorice root ingestion (especially in large amounts or over time) contains glycyrrhizin, which inhibits the enzyme 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 2 (11β-HSD2).
  • This enzyme normally converts cortisol to cortisone in the kidney.
  • Inhibition leads to excess cortisol acting on mineralocorticoid receptors, mimicking hyperaldosteronism.

Mechanism of SAME(syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess):

  • The glucocorticoid cortisol has equal affinity for the MLR to that of aldosterone, with resultant 'mineralocorticoid-like' activity.
  • However, cells in the aldosterone-sensitive distal nephron are protected from this 'illicit' activation by the enzyme 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase-2 (11βHSD-2), which converts cortisol to cortisone.
  • Cortisone has minimal affinity for the MLR. Recessive loss-of-function mutations in the 11βHSD-2 gene are thus associated with cortisol-dependent activation of the MLR and the syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME).
  • Encompassing hypertension, hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis, with suppressed PRA and suppressed aldosterone.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman was referred for investigation of progressive generalised muscle weakness and lethargy. She was taking no regular medications. Examination was unremarkable. Her blood pressure was 108/60 mmHg. Her body mass index was 20.Investigations:
Serum potassium 2.8mmol/L (3.5-4.9) serum bicarbonate 33 mmol/L (20-28)
Serum creatinine 77 -mol/L (60-110) eGFR >90 ml/min Serum magnesium 0.61 mmol/L (0.75-1.05)
Serum chloride 85 mmol/L (95-107)
Urinary chloride 61 mmol/L (NR: 25 to 40 mmol/L )
Urinary sodium 57 mmol/L (NR:~20 mmol/L)
24-hour urinary calcium 1.6 mmol (2.5-7.5)
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with:

  • Hypokalemia (K+ = 2.8 mmol/L)
  • Metabolic alkalosis (HCO3- = 33 mmol/L)
  • Hypomagnesemia (Mg2+ = 0.61 mmol/L)
  • Hypocalciuria (low 24-hr urinary calcium = 1.6 mmol)
  • Normotension (BP = 108/60 mmHg)
  • Normal renal function
  • Urine Na+ and Cl-are inappropriately high → renal salt wasting

The above description fits the diagnosis of Gitelman's syndrome.

Gitelman's syndrome:

A genetic defect in the Na+/Cl- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalciuria
  • Normal or low blood pressure

Explanation of other options:

Bartter's syndrome(Option A):

  • Also causes hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, but typically has normal or high urinary calcium (hypercalciuria), not low.
  • Seen in defects in the thick ascending limb (like a loop diuretic effect).

Hypokalemic periodic paralysis(Option C):

  • Would present with normal acid-base balance, not metabolic alkalosis.
  • It's a channelopathy and does not involve hypomagnesemia or hypocalciuria.

Liddle's syndrome(Option D):

  • Causes hypertension (due to increased ENaC activity), hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and suppressed renin and aldosterone.
  • This patient is normotensive, making Liddle's unlikely.

questions.text: Which of the following is the functional effect of Hypokalemia on kidney function?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The functional effects of hypokalemia on the kidney can include Na+-Cl- and HCO3 - retention, polyuria, phosphaturia, hypocitraturia, and an activation of renal ammoniagenesis. Bicarbonate retention and other acid-base effects of hypokalemia can contribute to the generation of metabolic alkalosis.
  • Hypokalemic polyuria is due to a combination of central polydipsia and an AVP-resistant renal concentrating defect.
  • Structural changes in the kidney due to hypokalemia include a relatively specific vacuolizing injury to proximal tubular cells, interstitial nephritis, and renal cysts.
  • Hypokalemia also predisposes to acute kidney injury and can lead to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in patients with long-standing hypokalemia due to eating disorders and/or laxative abuse.

Causes of Hypokalemia:

  • Hypokalemia may result from renal losses, gastrointestinal losses, or intracellular redistribution of K.
  • Renal losses that result in hypokalemia include K-wasting diuretics, osmotic diuresis, glucocorticoid excess, mineralocorticoid excess, and leukaemia.
  • Gastrointestinal losses that result in hypokalemia include diarrhoea, vomiting, nasogastric suction, and laxative abuse.
  • Redistribution of K may occur, resulting in hypokalemia, in patients who have been administered insulin or glucose, in patients treated with beta-adrenergic stimulation, and in patients with alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the ECG change seen specifically in severe Hyperkalemia (>8.0 mM)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hyperkalemia is a medical emergency due to its effects on the heart.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias associated with hyperkalemia include sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, slow idioventricular rhythms, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and asystole.

ECG changes in Hyperkalemia:

  • A mild increase in extracellular K+ affects the repolarisation phase of the cardiac action potential, resulting in changes in T-wave morphology. (Option D ruled out)
  • Further, an increase in plasma K+ concentration depresses intracardiac conduction, with progressive prolongation of the PR and QRS intervals. (Option B ruled out)
  • Severe hyperkalemia results in loss of the P wave and a progressive widening of the QRS complex; development of a sine-wave sinoventricular rhythm suggests impending ventricular fibrillation or asystole. (Option C ruled out)
  • Hyperkalemia can also cause a type I Brugada pattern in the electrocardiogram (ECG), with a pseudo-right bundle branch block and persistent coved ST segment elevation in at least two precordial leads.
  • This hyperkalemic Brugada's sign occurs in critically ill patients with severe hyperkalemia and can be differentiated from genetic Brugada's syndrome by an absence of P waves, marked QRS widening, and an abnormal QRS axis.
  • Classically, the electrocardiographic manifestations in hyperkalemia progress from tall peaked T waves (5.5-6.5 mM), to a loss of P waves (6.5-7.5 mM), to a widened QRS complex (7.0-8.0 mM), and, ultimately, to a sine wave pattern (>8.0 mM).
  • However, these changes are notoriously insensitive, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease or ESRD.

Management of Hyperkalemia:

  • Urgent management of hyperkalemia constitutes a 12-lead ECG, admission to the hospital, continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, and immediate treatment.
  • The treatment of hyperkalemia is generally divided into three categories: (1) antagonism of the cardiac effects of hyperkalemia; (2) rapid reduction in K+ by redistribution into cells; and (3) removal of K+ from the body.
  • Intravenous calcium is the first-line drug in the emergency management of hyperkalemia, even in patients with normal calcium levels.
  • The mutually antagonistic effects of calcium and K+ on the myocardium and the protective role of Ca2+in hyperkalemia have long been known.
  • The first line therapy for cardio-protection is calcium gluconate. Following this, insulin and dextrose should be given.

The following table shows the changes in the ECG:

questions.text: The mechanism of action of Patiromer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Novel intestinal potassium binders have recently become available for the management of hyperkalemia.
  • These agents appear to lack the intestinal toxicity of SPS (Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate).
  • Patiromer is a nonabsorbed polymer provided as a powder for suspension, which binds K+ in exchange for Ca2+.
  • In healthy adults, patiromer causes a decrease in urinary potassium, magnesium, and sodium excretion, suggesting the binding of the polymer to these cations in the intestine; notably, a side-effect of the medication is hypomagnesemia.
  • ZS-9 is an inorganic, nonabsorbable crystalline compound that exchanges both Na+ and H+ ions in exchange for K+ and NH4+ + in the intestine.
  • These agents promise to revolutionise the management of both chronic and acute hyperkalemia.
  • In particular, the availability of safe, well-tolerated potassium binders is expected to allow for greater intensity of RAAS inhibition in both renal and cardiac disease.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of Hypercalcemia, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Furosemide leads to calcium excretion, so it leads to Hypocalcemia.

The following table shows the causes of Hypercalcemia:

questions.text: All of the following are ECG changes of hypercalcemia, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypercalcemia can result in significant electrocardiographic changes, including bradycardia, AV block, and a short QT interval and not a broad QT interval. (Other options ruled out)
  • Changes in serum calcium can be monitored by following the QT interval.
  • Mild hypercalcemia (up to 11-11.5 mg/dL) is usually asymptomatic and recognised only on routine calcium measurements.
  • Some patients may complain of vague neuropsychiatric symptoms, including trouble concentrating, personality changes, or depression.
  • Other presenting symptoms may include peptic ulcer disease or nephrolithiasis, and fracture risk may be increased.
  • More severe hypercalcemia (>12-13 mg/dL), particularly if it develops acutely, may result in lethargy, stupor, or coma, as well as gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, anorexia, constipation, or pancreatitis).
  • Hypercalcemia decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia. With long-standing hyperparathyroidism, patients may present with bone pain or pathologic fractures.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of COPD and essential hypertension is admitted for recently exacerbated shortness of breath and easy fatigability. He is on bronchodilators and hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ). Laboratory value:

What is the acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The increases in HCO3 - and pCO2 indicate that the acid-base disorder is metabolic alkalosis.

  • Based on the respiratory response for metabolic alkalosis, the expected pCO2 should be (ΔHCO3- = 13 (37-24) * 0.7 = 13) = 53 (40 + 13) mmHg.
  • However, the reported pCO2 is 59 mmHg. Therefore, the acid-base is metabolic alkalosis superimposed on chronic respiratory acidosis.
  • The coexistence of metabolic alkalosis is due to HCTZ.

choices.text: Impaired renal excretion of excess bicarbonate

questions.text: Sustained metabolic alkalosis is always due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • While metabolic alkalosis is caused by a variety of factors, including chloride depletion, potassium depletion or increased secretion of mineralocorticoids, the result is always impaired renal excretion of excess bicarbonate. (Other options ruled out)
  • Metabolic alkalosis is established by an elevated arterial pH, an increase in the serum [HCO3 -], and an increase in Paco2 as a result of compensatory alveolar hypoventilation.
  • It is often accompanied by hypochloremia and hypokalemia.

Normally, excess bicarbonate is rapidly excreted by the kidneys by:

  • An increased filtered load, allowing additional bicarbonate to be delivered to the distal nephron;
  • Chloride-dependent secretion of bicarbonate by pendrin, in the cortical collecting duct
  • Down-regulation of H+ secretion in the cortical and medullary collecting duct.

Metabolic alkalosis occurs when abnormal H+ loss or bicarbonate administration is coupled with:

  • A reduced filtered load of bicarbonate (e.g., hypoperfusion of the kidney, advanced kidney disease);
  • Enhanced bicarbonate reabsorption along the tubule (e.g., effects of angiotensin II, aldosterone, hypokalemia);
  • Continued stimulation of H+ secretion by the α-intercalated cells in the collecting duct (e.g., primary hyperaldosteronism, chloride depletion)
  • Impaired bicarbonate secretion by pendrin (e.g., chloride depletion; advanced kidney disease).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of short-bowel surgery is seen for slurred speech, confusion, weakness, impaired motor coordination, and irritability. She likes ice cream and develops mild neurologic problems following large quantities of ice cream. She is not on any medications or special diets. ABG: pH 7.27, pCO2 24 mmHg, and calculated HCO3 - 16. Urine ketones are negative. Serum lactate levels are 1.5 mmol/L. Serum creatinine is normal. The anion gap is 20, but the osmolal gap is normal. Which one of the following is the MOST likely cause of this acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

D-Lactic acidosis, which may be associated with jejunoileal bypass, short bowel syndrome, or intestinal obstruction, is due to the formation of d-lactate by gut bacteria.

  • Symptoms typically present after the ingestion of high-carbohydrate feedings. Neurologic symptoms include altered mental status, slurred speech, and ataxia, with patients often appearing drunk.
  • The onset of neurologic symptoms is accompanied by metabolic acidosis and elevation of plasma D-lactate concentration.
  • In these patients, malabsorbed carbohydrate is fermented by an abnormal bacterial flora in the colon, which produces excessive amounts of D-lactate.
  • High amounts of D-lactate are absorbed into the circulation, resulting in an elevated concentration of D-lactate in the blood.
  • The lactate levels that are conventionally measured are L-lactate, which is the one that accumulates in tissue hypoxia.
  • The normal levels of L-lactate are < 2mmol/L/L. So definitely the answer is lactic acidosis caused by D-lactate.

Arrival at the diagnosis:

  • Here, the pH is 7.27, pCO2 is 24mm Hg, and HCO3 is 16. So there is metabolic acidosis. But the anion gap is 20, which is high.
  • High AG metabolic acidosis is seen in the accumulation of non-chloride-containing acids that include inorganic (phosphate, sulfate), organic (ketoacids, lactate, uremic organic anions), exogenous (salicylate or ingested toxins with organic acid production), or unidentified anions.
  • But here they say the osmolar gap is normal. Osmolar gap is the difference between the actual serum osmolarity and the calculated serum osmolarity.
  • Increased osmolar gap (defined as >10 mOsm/g ) is caused by hyperlipidemia or hyperproteinemia, sugars (mannitol, sorbitol), and alcohols.
  • Increased osmolar gap is clinically used to screen for toxic alcohol ingestion, such as ethanol or certain toxic alcohols, including methanol, ethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, propylene glycol, and isopropanol.
  • Since the osmolar gap is normal, methanol can be excluded.
  • Since there is no history of drug intake, topiramate can also be excluded.
  • So the two possible answers are pyroglutamic acid and lactic acid.
  • So let's get back to the clinical scenario. This metabolic abnormality is noted in a person who has undergone small bowel resection and who has altered sensorium following a high-carbohydrate ingestion.
  • This is seen with D-lactic acidosis.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of High Anion Gap metabolic acidosis, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diarrhoea is not a cause of HAGMA; Instead, it causes normal (non-anion gap) metabolic acidosis due to loss of bicarbonate in stool.

There are four principal causes of a high-AG acidosis:

  • Lactic acidosis(Option B)
  • Ketoacidosis(Option A)
  • Ingested toxins(Option C)
  • Acute and chronic renal failure

Causes of Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis:

  • Gastrointestinal Bicarbonate Loss:
    • Diarrhoea
    • Pancreatic fistulas
    • Ureterosigmoidostomy
    • Ileal conduits
  • Renal Bicarbonate Loss (Renal Tubular Acidosis - RTA):
    • Type 1 (Distal) RTA - impaired H+ secretion
    • Type 2 (Proximal) RTA - impaired HCO3- reabsorption
    • Type 4 RTA - hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance (often with hyperkalemia)
  • Drugs & Toxins:
    • Acetazolamide (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor → proximal RTA)
    • Topiramate (also inhibits carbonic anhydrase)
    • Amphotericin B (damages distal tubules → distal RTA)
    • Ifosfamide
    • Trimethoprim, pentamidine (mimic aldosterone deficiency → Type 4 RTA)

Key takeaways:

  • Because of the association of metabolic acidosis in advanced CKD with muscle catabolism, bone disease and more rapid progression of CKD, both the 'uremic acidosis' of ESRD and the non-AG metabolic acidosis of stages 3 and 4 CKD require oral alkali replacement to maintain the [HCO3 −] to approximately the normal value (25 mmol/L).
  • This can be accomplished with relatively modest amounts of alkali (1.0-1.5 mmol/kg body weight per day). Either NaHCO3 tablets (650-mg tablets contain 7.8 meq) or sodium citrate (Shohl's solution) is effective.

choices.text: Type IV RTA with aldosterone deficiency

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for left flank pain and hematuria. Urinalysis reveals a pH of 6.9 and hematuria only. There is no evidence of UTI. Renal ultrasound shows the presence of kidney stones. He has no deafness. Serum chemistry and ABG show mild hypokalemic hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. Serum creatinine is normal. He has a family history of kidney stones, and several members have mild hypokalemic hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. Which one of the following renal tubular acidoses (RTAs) is the MOST likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with:
    • Left flank pain and hematuria
    • Kidney stones
    • Urine pH = 6.9 (alkaline)
    • Hypokalemic hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis (normal anion gap)
    • Normal serum creatinine
    • Family history of stones and RTA
    • No hearing loss
  • This confirms that the patient has a hereditary form of distal RTA with autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • It occurs in adults.
  • Autosomal recessive forms are diagnosed in infancy and childhood with or without deafness.
  • Hyperkalemic RTA with a defect in the voltage gradient is seen in patients with mild to moderate renal dysfunction.

Most important causes of distal RTA:

  • Sjögren's syndrome (most common acquired cause)
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Amphotericin B (nephrotoxic antifungal)
  • Ifosfamide (chemotherapy agent)
  • Inherited mutations (e.g., SLC4A1, ATP6V1B1, ATP6V0A4)
  • Obstructive uropathy
  • Chronic interstitial nephritis

Explanation of other options:

Proximal RTA(Option A): Urine pH would fall below 5.5 over time, and stones are not typical.

Type IV RTA with Aldosterone deficiency (Option C): Features hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia. It can be seen with Addison's disease due to damage to the adrenal gland by viruses (HIV, CMV), bacteria (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), or fungal agents.

Incomplete RTA(Option D): Would be milder and usually diagnosed on urine acidification testing, but this patient has overt acidosis and stones.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old female student is admitted for confusion and acute kidney injury. She can give some history that she fought with her boyfriend 2 days ago, and she drank some liquid that was in their garage. She has no other significant medical or illicit drug history. In the Emergency Department, her vital signs are stable. Other than altered mental status and confusion, her physical examination is normal. She weighs 60 kg. Laboratory values:

Which one of the following toxic alcohol ingestions is the MOST likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has a high AG metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis. She also has an osmolal gap of 16, which is elevated.
  • The presence of calcium oxalate crystals (envelope-like) in the urine sediment is a clue to her acid-base disturbance, which is ethylene glycol ingestion.
  • One of the final products of ethylene glycol is oxalic acid, which is excreted as oxalate.

Management of Ethylene Glycol toxicity:

  • The antidote for ethylene glycol is fomepizole. The initial dose is 15 mg/kg, followed by 10 mg/kg every 12 h for 4 doses. Continue fomepizole, if ethylene glycol levels are not below 20 mg/dL.
  • At the same time, hydration with D5W and 3 ampules (150 mEq) of NaHCO3 to run at 120 mL/h to improve volume status should be started.
  • Hemodialysis is indicated if no improvement in renal function and metabolic acidosis following adequate hydration and NaHCO3 administration is observed.

Explanation of other options:

Ethanol(Option A): Causes CNS depression but not typically AKI or metabolic acidosis

Methanol(Option C): Causes visual disturbances and CNS symptoms, less commonly AKI

Toluene(Option D): Found in glue/solvents, but causes RTA, hypokalemia, not AKI

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of metabolic alkalosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acetaminophen is not a cause of the metabolic alkalosis.

  • Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is not associated with acid-base disturbances unless in overdose.
  • Acetaminophen-induced high-AG metabolic acidosis is uncommon but is being recognised more often in either patient with acetaminophen overdose or malnourished or critically ill patients receiving acetaminophen in typical dosage.
  • 5-Oxoproline accumulation after acetaminophen should be suspected in the setting of an unexplained high-AG acidosis without elevation of the osmolar gap in patients receiving acetaminophen.
  • The various causes of metabolic alkalosis are summarised in the Table below.
  • In attempting to establish the cause of metabolic alkalosis, one must assess the clinical circumstance (e.g., diuretics, vomiting) and the status of the ECF volume, blood pressure, serum K+ concentration, and, in some cases, the renin-aldosterone system.
  • Urine electrolyte determinations and urine screening for diuretics are helpful diagnostic tools.

choices.text: Nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors in HIV

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of Type B lactic acidosis, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carbon Monoxide is a cause of type A lactic acidosis and not type B lactic acidosis.

An increase in plasma l-lactate may be secondary:

  • Poor tissue perfusion (type A):
    • Circulatory insufficiency (shock, cardiac failure)
    • Severe anaemia, mitochondrial enzyme defects
    • Inhibitors (carbon monoxide, cyanide)
  • Aerobic disorders (type B):
    • Malignancies
    • Nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors in HIV(Option A)
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Renal or hepatic failure
    • Thiamine deficiency(Option B)
    • Severe infections (cholera, malaria)
    • Seizures
    • Drugs/ toxins (biguanides, ethanol, and the toxic alcohols: ethylene glycol (EG), methanol, or propylene glycol). (Option D)
